popup.title: Objective
popup.content: Please visit our page to learn about microscope objectives

popup.title: Media
popup.content: The immersion medium corresponding with selected objective. Learn more about immersion media and refractive index here

popup.title: NA
popup.content: Numerical Aperture (NA) is a unit-less measurement of the light gathering ability of an objective lens. Learn more about NA here

popup.title: Field of View
popup.content: Field of View is the diameter of the illuminated field measured at the intermediate image plane. Learn more about FOV here

popup.title: Exmax / Emmax
popup.content: The excitation/emission maximum (Exmax) is the wavelength of maximum absorption/emission by a fluorescent molecule, measured in nanometers (nm). Learn more about fluorescence microscopy here

popup.title: Emmax
popup.content: The emission maximum (Emmax) is the wavelength of maximum emission by a fluorescent molecule, measured in nanometers (nm). Learn more about fluorescence microscopy here

popup.title: Camera
popup.content: This list contains common CCD, EM-CCD, and sCMOS camera models for use with light microscopes. Learn more about digital imaging here

popup.title: Binning
popup.content: The accumulated charge from adjacent camera pixels may be combined to form a reduced number of “superpixels”. Learn more about binning and other digital camera functions here

popup.title: Camera Relay
popup.content: Relay optics may be used to provide additional image magnification. Learn more about magnification here

popup.title: Illumination
popup.content: Illumination may be performed in a transmitted light (diascopic) or reflected light (episcopic) geometry. Learn more about the microscope optical train here

popup.title: Modality
popup.content: Three different episcopic imaging modes are available for selection widefield, spinning disk confocal, and point-scanning confocal. Learn more about confocal microscopy here

popup.title: Active Pixels
popup.content: Expressed as the number of pixels in the x and y directions, respectively, on the camera chip. Refers to number of pixels scanned in x and y directions for point-scanning confocals. Learn more about digital cameras here

popup.title: Real Pixel Size
popup.content: The actual size of each pixel on the camera. Learn more about digital cameras here

popup.title: Backprojected Pixel Size
popup.content: This is the virtual, de-magnified size of a camera pixel when back-projected into the specimen plane. Learn more about digital cameras here

popup.title: Sensor Dimensions
popup.content: This is the physical length and width of the camera chip, expressed in millimeters (mm). Learn more about digital cameras here

popup.title: Illuminated Sample Imaged
popup.content: This is proportion of the total illuminated area imaged by the camera and expressed as a percentage. A field diaphragm may be used to limit illumination to the imaged area. Learn more about FOV here

popup.title: Total Magnification
popup.content: The total magnification of the imaging system, found by taking the product of the objective magnification and any additional camera relay magnification (or zoom for point-scanning confocal). Learn more about magnification here

popup.title: Lateral Resolution
popup.content: Lateral resolution refers to the optical resolution in the x and y directions and values calculated using the Rayleigh Criterion. Learn more about resolution here

popup.title: Axial Resolution
popup.content: Axial resolution refers to the optical resolution in the z directions and values calculated using the Rayleigh Criterion. Learn more about resolution here

popup.title: Sampling Rate
popup.content: The sampling rate is provided as the ratio of the calculated lateral resolution to the size of the back-projected pixel. Learn about Nyquist Sampling here

popup.title: Brightness
popup.content: Brightness is a unit-less value describing the light-gathering power of the objective. Learn more about brightness here

popup.title: Pinhole Diameter
popup.content: The actual diameter of the pinhole aperture(s) in a spinning disk or point-scanning confocal microscope. Learn more about the confocal pinhole here

popup.title: Backprojected Pinhole Radius
popup.content: The radius of the image of the confocal pinhole projected into the specimen plane. Learn more about the confocal pinhole here

popup.title: Airy Units
popup.content: Airy Units (AU) is calculated by finding the ratio of the back-projected pinhole radius to the radius of the Airy Disk formed by a single emitter. If AU = 1, then the back-projected pinhole radius is equal to the radius of the Airy Disk. Learn more about the confocal pinhole here

popup.title: Condenser Media
popup.content: This refers to the condenser lens immersion medium, typically either air or oil. Learn more about the microscope optical train here

popup.title: Condenser NA
popup.content: The numerical aperture (NA) of the condenser lens. Learn more about the microscope optical train here

popup.title: Model
popup.content: Information on Nikon confocal microscopes may be found here

popup.title: Active Pixels (x)
popup.content: The number of pixels the image is partitioned into along the length of the x-axis.

popup.title: Active Pixels (y)
popup.content: The number of pixels the image is partitioned into along the length of the y-axis.

popup.title: Confocal Aperture Dimensions
popup.content: The real space dimensions over which the excitation laser may be scanned, corresponding to maximum deflection angle of the scanning mirrors.

popup.title: Virtual Pixel Size
popup.content: The size of a single pixel in an image built using a point-scanning confocal system.
